review.title: An Approach to Speed-up the Word Sense Disambiguation Procedure through Sense Filtering
review.abstract: In this paper, we are going to focus on speed up of the Word Sense Disambiguation procedure by filtering the relevant senses of an ambiguous word through Part-of-Speech Tagging. First, this proposed approach performs the Part-of-Speech Tagging operation before the disambiguation procedure using Bigram approximation. As a result, the exact Part-of-Speech of the ambiguous word at a particular text instance is derived. In the next stage, only those dictionary definitions (glosses) are retrieved from an online dictionary, which are associated with that particular Part-of-Speech to disambiguate the exact sense of the ambiguous word. In the training phase, we have used Brown Corpus for Part-of-Speech Tagging and WordNet as an online dictionary. The proposed approach reduces the execution time upto half (approximately) of the normal execution time for a text, containing around 200 sentences. Not only that, we have found several instances, where the correct sense of an ambiguous word is found for using the Part-of-Speech Tagging before the Disambiguation procedure.

First, this proposed approach performs the Part-of-Speech Tagging operation before performing the Disambiguation Procedure using Bigram Approximation. As a result, the exact Part-of-Speech of the ambiguous word is derived from a particular text instance. In the next step, only those dictionary definitions (glosses) are retrieved from an online dictionary associated with that particular Part-of-Speech in order to clarify the exact meaning of the ambiguous word.In the training phase, we have used Brown Corpus for Part-of-Speech Tagging and WordNet as an online dictionary to shorten the execution time up to (approximately) half of the execution text for a sentence that does not contain multiple sentences.

sections.heading: 2. THEORETICAL BACKGROUND
sections.text: The most common unmonitored WSD algorithm is Lesk Algorithm, which uses WordNet as an online dictionary. The algorithm is briefly described below:

sections.heading: 2.1 Preliminaries of Lesk Algorithm
sections.text: The typical reading algorithm selects a short phrase from the sentence containing an ambiguous word. Then, the dictionary definition (gloss) of each of the meanings of the ambiguous word is compared with the gloss of the other words of that particular sentence. An ambiguous word is assigned to the respective meaning whose gloss has the highest number of overlaps (number of common words) with the gloss of the other words in the sentence. Example 1: "Aries and Sita go to the bank every day to withdraw money." Here, the expression is taken according to the window size (number of consecutive words). If window size is 3, then the phrase would be "Bank Withdrawal." All other words are discarded as "Stopwords." sections.heading: 2.2 Simple (unsmoothed) N-gram and Bigram Model
sections.text: N-gram [32] is used to calculate the probability of a complete word sequence (which can be represented either as w1.... wn or w1 n). If each word is considered as an independent event in its proper position, the probability is represented as follows: P (W1, W2,......, Wn-1, Wn).The chain rule for breaking down probability would be: P (W1 n) = P (W1) P (W2 | W1) P (W3 | W1 2).... P (Wn | W1 n-1).But calculating the probability like P (Wn | W1 n-1) is not easy for a long sequence of preceding words. The Bigram model approaches the probability of a word in relation to all preceding words P (Wn | W1 n-1) at the conditional probability of the preceding word P (Wn | Wn-1).

sections.heading: 5. OUTPUT AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: The algorithm is tested on more than 100 texts of varying lengths and categories, with an average length of 200 sentences, selecting two ambiguous words for testing: "Bank" and "Plant." Next, the simplified reading algorithm is applied to the input text containing the POS-marked ambiguous word. As the POS of the ambiguous word is derived earlier, only the dictionary definitions from WordNet for the WSD process that belong to the same POS domain as the POS of the ambiguous word are selected. As a result, the execution time of the WSD process is shortened (see Table 5). It is also observed that as the relevant glosses for the WSD process are taken into account, the accuracy of the ambiguous meaning is increased (see text no. 10). Some of the results of the target word "Bank" are given in the sense of Table 5. All sample texts are taken from "wiikia.com."

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: The proposed approach speeds up the WSD procedure by filtering the only relevant glosses and also increases the accuracy of the WSD procedure. Time differences between the two cases (with and without POS tagging procedure) could be increased if few system calls and other system-related tasks are handled properly. The obvious operations (loop, memory allocation, status check, function call, etc.) for POS tagging took some time, which is included in the cited result. Otherwise, the actual time difference could have been better.
